reviews.review_msg: One of the worst profs I have ever had during my undergrad years. Uses slides directly from a textbook he helped write, but has no idea how to explain any fundamental details of the slides. We were allowed 2 double-sided cheat sheets for the midterm and the class average was still under 50%.

Ended up being a very hard course. Assignments were on the whole quite easy, but tests were very difficult focusing on seemingly random facts. He lets you have a bunch of cheat sheets for the final, but it is still difficult requiring a very throughout knowledge of all of the codecs discussed in the notes. Most would be best off avoiding this class

He assumes everybody in the class is a multimedia genius, given how hard this area is.He usually only spend couple of mins on explaining a complex algorithm orally without any hand written on the board.Those things are not easy for anyone who has never touched this area.How can this course be an introduction,with being taught by this guy?Cmon SFU!!

I got A- for ENSC 424, which is also the Multimedia course. However,I am still not able to follow how this guy teach.His assignments have nothing to do with the materials he would like to test.His exams keep focusing on useless, tiny things from the book.Even with prior experience in this area,I still complain about the way he teaches this course
in terms of personality, he is very nice, but in terms of teaching skill, he is very poor,totally don't know how to teach

Take this course with the prof only if you have advanced knowledge in multimedia.funny how this course is supposed to be an introduction. the textbook or lectures dont help. those who have prior knowledge were at an advantage.Began with so much energy finished with no enthusiasm whatsoever. I never want to do anything multimedia again because of hi
Admittedly, he is a nice person. However, the test and assignment are so hard to finish. This course should be ten credits according to the difficulty right now.
tough professor and TA ever.

He is a nice person. BUT he does not know how to teach at all!! lectures are extremely unclear,jumps from here to there,strong accent, the worst one I've seen in SFU. Assignments are very difficult!For suitable for graduate students, not for undergrads.Do yourself a favor and avoid him.

Lectures are very boring and filled with a lot of material we didn't need to know for tests. Lectures are not recorded so i would recommend going. Coding projects were not bad and not harshly marked. Exams were similar to homework questions and he told us mostly exactly what would be on it. Overall a nice prof but bad lectures

Very boring and monotone lectures. And if the difficulty of the lectures was 2, then the exams would be 12. Not fun. 
Very tough grader.

This class was my first 300 level course, it was really bad. Can't stay focused for more than 10 minutes really boring. Get ready to study everything by yourself, exams are hard, the grading is crazy tough, but it isn't that hard to learn on your own, don't expect to learn that much. The way he replies to emails is unprofessional & annoying.

He is very knowledgeable in his area of research, and the topics taught are interesting. Thanks to the circumstances at SFU the difficulty was SIGNIFICANTLY lower - a lot of extensions and watered down quizzes. Textbook did a poor job at explaining things; slides might be better but not by a lot. Had to constantly refer to external sources.

Pretty low effort prof. Bad lecture notes that are organized terribly. Very silly assignment deadlines and other course component deadlines at the same time in the same day (6pm lol). Intentionally feels like he makes easy content harder by doing a bad job of explaining it or assuming that the people he is teaching are knowledgeable on said topic.

Lectures are pretty dry and due to a lack of recordings, you have to go in-person to them. Assignments were pretty easy and exams were based off lectures + written assignments making them feel very fair. Overall, the class was informative and I enjoyed the assignments because they applied the topics we learned to real world applications.
Professor JC is really nice person. Hard work, then you can get what you expect.

First, take math 242 before this. It's not listed as a prereq but it should be. JC teaches the course with a focus on how to design multimedia applications rather than using them, which is really interesting. Lots of material but for exams you only need to remember what he stresses. The projects can be challenging. You get back what you put in.

JC is a quite helpful and nice prof. The two projects are related to the course content and you can learn a lot if you really put effort on them. The exam is fair and not difficult if you know concepts well.

He's wonderful. His midterms and finals are pretty easy. Almost two thirds students finished the final exam in just one hour. If you always attend his lectures, you will find that several final questions that look difficult have been discussed during lectures. You cannot benefit from that if you only attend few lectures.

Most things covered in lectures are not difficult. Midterms are based on the homework and his lecture slides. DO NEED to attend lectures as he will tell you what you need to memorize and how the exam will be organized. The projects are interesting and not that difficult.

I understood the super high level concepts but once he started explaining the details in class, I didnt understand what he was saying at all. Class was weird because I felt like I was going fail , but yet I got an A. I did however complete the project, even though my partner contributed 0% to it and also got that person an A.

Does not put any work into preparing for classes. Every lecture felt like he was working with a vague idea of what he wanted to teach and was frequently surprised by his own slides. Certainly knows his stuff but not a great teacher.

His class is very interesting. I really enjoyed the content. If you want to get a good grade just go to every class and actually listen to him. There is no chance you will get a bad grade if you do that.

I've got a 3.8 GPA and this guy made me just not even show up to class. Worst professor I've ever had. I aspire to be a teacher one day and from this man, I've learned one thing: how to be a terrible teacher.

The course overall had interesting material but the lectures were often hard to follow, enough that attending lectures become more or less optional. Tests are tough with some questions never fully covered in the course but the bulk of the mark is in the projects, which you are almost guaranteed an A if you put any work in it.

Nice enough guy but terrible teacher. Jumps all over the place with material and uploads terrible quality scanned notes that he has been using since the early 2000's. Class content is interesting but with Mark the focus is always on heavily outdated technology that is tough to relate to. Says tests will be "easy" but includes concepts never covered

Went to his office hr and no one was in line. First thing he said was he's busy so make it quick. I asked him my questions which he made everything more confusing, then told me to come back later. There was 15 min of office hr left with no one behind me. I dont think he gets what office hrs are for. He clearly doesn't care if you learn or not.

Most confusing and scattered lectures ever.  Every example "looks like a good midtermfinal question". By the 4th week only 15 people are still attending lecture because it's so USELESS. The assignments are random and pointless. You will NOT learn anything, but only rip your hair out worrying about failing. Do yourself a favor - AVOID AVOID AVOID.

Easy grader, I barely learned anything in this course, teaches fast. Almost failed both exams but final grade was around an A. The 2nd assignment and project was extremely difficult. However, he gives everyone extremely good marks for the effort. My programs basically did not do what he asked and I still managed to get a good grade.
Not a hard course to ace, but don't expect to learn a lot
It's not hard to get a pass, but it's really hard to understand the content. Not recommend to take it with this prof.
He's a good prof, teaches well.

He wrote the textbook, but it is outdated (ten years). His main problem is that he does not understand how much time is needed to answer his exam questions. Even if you know all the answers, there is no time to write them down. So everybody gets the same mark, whether or not you knew the answers! No time for writing the answers anyway.

He wrote the textbook and is a treasure trove of knowledge. The assignments can be difficult as lot of students seem to cheat on the project which translates to a lot of work you have to do for equal quality.
Fantastically knowledgeable. Nice attitude toward the students and class. Really energetic. Gorgeous personality.
nice prof. He knows his stuff very well. Hard exams though.

You've got to give this prof a chance.  He does come off as goofy and uncaring at times but he really knows his stuff and you will learn it if you apply yourself.  His lectures  are entertaining and his assignments are fair. He puts a large emphasis on effort, so if he sees you tried you will do well.  A good professor, try his course!
great prof.

It is obvious from his lectures that he has no interest in the course. He wasted many lectures showing past student projects and rushed through harder part of the course. His exams test your application of the course materials, which was never covered in lectures and assignments, thus giving you no practice beforehand and no chance to prepare.
goofy, but good prof, pretty easy the only hard part of this course was the 2nd assignment. laugh at his jokes maybe you'll get a good mark.

Knows his material very well, maybe a little too well, as he assumes we should easily be able to follow his chicken scratch notes. Doesn't know how to TEACH, and midterm/final was misleading. VERY disorganized prof. Good sense of humor but that's the only good thing about him.

Was a reasonably hard course, but not unexpected for an upper division cmpt sci course.  GOOD communication skills, is a native english speaker unlike some other profs in this faculty.  Excellent course material if you're willing to work at understanding it.
loved the multimedia projects, but lectures were very difficult to follow for non-native-english speakers. no textbook used.

He is knowledgeable in multimedia, but when it comes to teaching, he doesn't know jack. His midterm and final are way out of whack. Advice: don't even bother study for the final, he is going to make u cry anyways.
Disorganised prof and unclear on what we actually need to know...
Unpredictable on tests...
Part marks for everything..quote:  My second cousin once removed.. ..corny jokes
Funny and exotic teaching style.  The harder you work, the better mark you get.
The most boring CMPT course I have taken. Not to mention bad lecturer.
Very disorganised notes and lectures.  Very bad teaching skills - unclear.
He is nice prof but exam..................
A multimedia professor whose notes are a multimedia mess.  Very confusing style.

I enjoyed his class very much. He called out people to answer question, that is why we have class participation, get it?. If you want to sit there just doze off, of course you are going to be mad about it, HAHA! If you do not plan to learn anything or be a lazy student, stay away from him. Otherwise, you will learn a great deal!
I would stay away from this instructor.  I hate how he likes to call out people in class.  He is not really clear on what he expects for the class project.

Keep away from us! No demonstration of rational thought or constructive criticism. Guard your name, he make you do anything! Also, in denial as he believes enough time for semester group project. Start mid Feb after 7+ futile negotiations! Is project "open idea"? Unchanged when enter-left this course. Can't believe he's teaching another CMPT course
The worst prof in computing science.  Not even fit to be a TA.

An awesome instructor. The lectures were super clear, and you don't really need to read the book to get the concepts. Assignments were graded pretty generously. The exams can be a bit tricky, but everything comes straight from the book or lectures.

David was an excellent instructor. He explained concepts clearly, supported students well, and made lectures engaging. Midterm 1 and the final were tough, but he adjusts grading fairly, so there's no need to worry.
best prof, very lenient and kind

I had him as a guest lecturer in cmpt365 for two weeks. I can tell he enjoys the content he is teaching and he knows his stuff. He has good examples to improve your understanding and tries to show real life applications. He also keeps the class interesting and lighthearted with small jokes.
I took CMPT225 with him. He is a good instructor who knows how to warm up the class, and he is nice to every student!

David is a great professor. He's very approachable and friendly to questions. You can tell he isn't jaded from teaching (yet) compared to some other profs and still has that young person energy. The content is interesting and structured well. Exams are fair (though mt1 was on the harder end). Would take a course with David again!

Professor David is truly an outstanding educator and one of the most impactful professors I've had the pleasure of learning from. His deep knowledge of the subject matter is evident in every lecture, where he effortlessly combines complex concepts with real-world examples, making even the most challenging material accessible and engaging.
Very good!

Professor David is a fantastic instructor who genuinely cares about his students' success. He was very responsive to emails and patiently answered questions after lectures. The course covers various media representations, including audio, images, and video, and their lossless and lossy compression methods. Highly recommended for anyone interested.
His lecture slides are not the best and are vague, he will be available for you if you have any questions. Cool, respectful, and nice guy.

Prof. David is a great professor. His lectures were quite clear and he made best efforts to listen to the students in between class to answer their questions. He replies to emails and discussions with rapid speed. There are pop up quizes at times that count towards participation so make sure to attend the class. Overall, amazing prof!
